awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Kinship Relations and Genetic Testing Technologies among Adult Adoptees
awd_abstract_narration:
The introduction of direct-to-consumer (DTC) genetics testing has radically altered the landscape of birth family search. The research supported by this award will investigate the scales at which DNA testing reinforces or challenges existing frameworks of family, identity, citizenship, and belonging. Ethnographically, it focuses on the discourses, practices, and policies surrounding DTC genetic testing technologies used by adult adoptees. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the researcher will produce a guidebook for policymakers, government officials, social workers, educators, and fellow researchers to understand the implications of genetic testing and the birth family search experience. 

This doctoral dissertation research project asks how DNA testing reinforces or challenges existing frameworks of family, identity, citizenship, and the nation, focusing on a research context with a historically high concentration of adoptions and the proliferating use of DTC genetic testing technologies among those adoptees. Participant observation will be carried out with four organizations that offer genetic testing services to adoptees and birth families. DNA testing has the potential to expose trauma on individual, familial, and national scales, as well as raise significant social, legal, and moral questions. Across this network of social actors and institutions, this research asks how DNA is being imagined, constructed, and deployed to produce personal and public knowledge of identity, kinship, citizenship, belonging, and memory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was guided by the following research questions: 1) How do both longstanding cultural constructions of kinship and emerging understandings of DNA influence attitudes and practices around genetic testing?; 2) What kinds of relations are being produced through access to genetic information atindividual, familial, national, and transnational levels?; and 3) What is the social, political, and legal potential of DNA? 

To answer this question, the co-PI conducted fourteen months of ethnographic fieldwork by carrying out participant observation at three organizations that offer services to adoptees and birth families. While all three are physically located in Seoul, South Korea, they operate at local, national, and transnational scales through both in-person and online projects. The co-PI also interviewed civil servants and employees at related government agencies, adoption agencies, and NGO and advocacy groups. Additionally, as a fourth site of inquiry, the co-PI monitored online groups where adoptees from all over the world congregate to discuss birth family search and genetic testing. 

By tracking the processes by which Korean adoptees and birth parents consider and use genetic technologies, and how they act (or do not act) upon genetic information, this project explores how existing social, cultural, and legal meanings of "family" and "nation" are being influenced by genetics and DNA testing in an era of globalization, transnationalism, and migration. For the previous three decades, adoptees had to rely almost entirely on records held by adoption agencies, often with sloppy or even fabricated records (E. Kim 2019). When adoption records offered no identifiable information, adoptees had few options besides sheer footwork, traveling to South Korea to pass out flyers and knock on doors orappearing on television to make emotional appeals (Prebin 2013, H. Kim 2016). Preliminary findings of this research show that many adoptees are now sidestepping information gatekeeping institutions (Klotz 2016), upending the birth family search process. The South Korean government has also entered the genetic testing arena, announcing in December 2019 that it would offer services enabling adoptees to submit their DNA at diplomatic missions in fourteen countries. During her fieldwork, the co-PI discovered several other DNA databases currently managed by the South Korean government to reunite the remains of fallen soldiers from the Korean War, the remains of the victims of the Jeju Uprising, and North-South Korean separated families. It is clear that the South Korean government views DNA as a tool to build its nationalist state narratives and national memory. The inclusion of adoptees to the "ethnonation," however, presents a more ambiguous case than fallen soldiers or independence fighters. Adoptees embody traumatic personal and familial histories that expose a shameful side to the country's rapid economic development-namely, that transnational adoption was an economically profitable way to raise foreign capital while outsourcing the state's social welfare costs. DNA connects adoptees to families, who through memory and storytelling (Mohatt et al. 2014) testify to past traumas and their still reverberating effects in the present on individual, familial, and national scales. Thus, this project asks how DNA's scientific authority (Bauer, Petkova and Boyadijieva, 2000) and the relationships it produces might engender alternative counterhegemonic memories.

Intellectual Merit:
Anthropologists have used transnational adoption as a lens to analyze the constructedness of categories of kinship, family, race, and nation, particularly in relation to globalization processes (Volkman 2005). This project builds on existing studies of kinship and genetics by asking how the scientific authority embodied by DNA influences the ways people conceive of, negotiate, and perform kinship and nation, in a transnationally connected world. This project also puts anthropological research on South Korea in dialogue with emergent research in critical adoption studies to illuminate the gendered and economic hierarchies of power that undergird South Korea's international adoption program. In particular, this project commits significant attention to birth family members who have largely been ignored by social workers, policymakers, and academia. Finally, without assuming the primacy of biogenetic relations, this project builds upon a nascent body of research on restorative justice by considering the political, social, cultural, and legal potential of genetic testing in acts of reclamation and the production of counter-memory. In doing so, this project contributes to a growing body of transnational research on state accountability and reconciliation.

Broader Impacts
Data collected will be used to produce scholarship in English and Korean to be submitted to peer-reviewed journals in hopes of contributing to discourses in anthropology, Korean studies, kinship studies, adoption studies, and restorative justice. In order to share research results with a wider audience, the co-PI will present findings at adoption and kinship-related conferences or workshops, as well as larger conferences and related government organizations. In addition, the co-PI will produce a guidebook in English and Korean for policymakers, government officials, social workers, educators, and researchers in order to understand implications of genetic testing and improve the birth family search experience.
